author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Campuses Are Virus Incubators, but These Colleges Can’t Require Vaccines
description: University of Texas at San Antonio will begin with mostly remote classes, because of the city’s high infection rates. Other schools are trying to avoid that fate.
content: It is what many universities fear. After months of gearing up for a fall semester that seemed like normal, with in-person classes and packed football games, the University of Texas at San Antonio announced Wednesday that almost all courses will be held online for the first three weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: The Elan of Elon Musk
description: A longtime critic of the Tesla chief executive explains why his bets against the car company haven’t paid off.
content: Much has been written about Carson Block, the volatile and sometimes venomous short-seller who runs Muddy Waters Capital. Now, Block is penning some rare words of his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Her Books Show the Lifestyles of the Fictional and Famous. She’s Poised for Some Fame of Her Own.
description: Taylor Jenkins Reid, the author of “Daisy Jones & the Six” and one of this summer’s hits, “Malibu Rising,” is tapping into the desire among readers (and Hollywood) for escapism plus complexity.
content: If Taylor Jenkins Reid were writing herself into one of her novels, which include “The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo,” “Daisy Jones & the Six” and this year’s “Malibu Rising,” she might slip in a scene where, roaming the stacks of a university library in Boston, she comes across “Starring Roles,” the 1992 book by Ron Base that explores the trajectory of actors like Judy Garland and Dustin Hoffman, whose careers were transformed by roles that nearly went to others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Satow
title: Are the Kids All Right? Ask the Camp Directors.
description: Summer camp in the middle of a pandemic has been a tech-free, joyous balm for some. For others, though, it’s a pit of anxiety.
content: Jack Spiro celebrated his elementary school graduation in 2020 from the back seat of his mother’s Toyota Highlander, as part of a drive-by ceremony. Then his first year in middle school, in Westchester, was mostly online. Whenever Jack, now 12,  got a chance to attend class in person, his best friend, who has diabetes, was never there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The New New Deal and Old Pitfalls
description: As Biden seeks to anoint himself the next Franklin Roosevelt, he should avoid repeating some of his predecessor’s mistakes.
content: President Biden’s grand plan to deliver a new New Deal that will “build back better,” transform American infrastructure and bounce the country back from the pandemic moved one step closer to reality this week when the Senate, with bipartisan support, approved the $1 trillion infrastructure bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: I Joined a Penguin NFT Club Because Apparently That’s What We Do Now
description: Is this what the metaverse looks like?
content: Earlier this week, I got attacked by penguins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Reeves and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: Children Listen
description: Roger Reeves gives us something we must remind children, something about how we’re not always right when we predict doom.
content: ‘‘You must grow wildly over the graves’’ rings too true for what many of us have known, for what many of us must find ways to tell our children. I write this thinking about Emmett Till and about how a more horrifying story is the burying of a child. But I also write thinking about the tomorrows of the children we’re trying to love today. Roger Reeves gives us something we must remind them, something about how we’re not always right when we predict doom — and maybe, just maybe, our children must become something we can’t fully name to make this earth right again.  Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: At MoMA, Love of Cars Can Be Exhausting
description: “Automania” airlifts nine cars into the sculpture garden and galleries. But it’s harder now to think of cars as objects of beauty.
content: In 1974 Andy Warhol bought himself a two-tone Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow — brown roof, black doors — custom-ordered from London. It didn’t matter that Warhol had no driver’s license. For some a car is more than a vehicle, and in “Automania,” the Museum of Modern Art’s engine-revving summer show, the automobile appears as an art object all its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Brendan Dougherty
title: Pope Francis Is Tearing the Catholic Church Apart
description: Pope Francis’ move against the Latin Mass will deepen the divisions in the church.
content: In the summer of 2001, I drove up to Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to find what we called “the traditional Latin Mass,” the form of Roman Catholic worship that stretched back centuries and was last authorized in 1962, before the Second Vatican Council changed everything. Back then, conservative Catholics called people who sought it out “schismatics” and “Rad Trads.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani and Niki Kitsantonis
title: Europe may have hit its hottest temperature on record amid devastating wildfires and floods.
description: A monitoring station in Sicily reached nearly 120 degrees Fahrenheit. And at least five children were missing as flash floods swept through northern Turkey.
content: A monitoring station on the Italian island of Sicily reached a scorching temperature of 48.8 degrees Celsius, or 119.84 degrees Fahrenheit, on Wednesday. If verified by the World Meteorological Organization, it would mark the hottest temperature ever recorded in Europe, topping the previous record of 48 degrees set in Athens in July 1977.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: New York City adds 629,000 people, defying predictions of its decline.
description: The city has grown nearly 8 percent since 2010, and now has 8.8 million residents, the census showed. One reason is a more accurate count, officials said.
content: New York City has grown by more than 629,000 people — or nearly 8 percent — since 2010, reaching 8.8 million and defying predictions that its population was on the decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Catching Up With One of the First Covid Patients to Be Put on a Ventilator
description: When he was admitted to the hospital, David Lat was one of a dozen New Yorkers there with Covid. When he finally left, the city was on lockdown. He’s made some changes since then.
content: David Lat, a writer and lawyer, was one of the first New Yorkers to grow critically ill with Covid-19 in March 2020. He was in the hospital for 17 days, including six days on a ventilator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Cuomo Is Resigning, but Some Legislators Still Want to Impeach Him
description: The New York State Assembly could still move to impeach the governor, but many high-ranking Democrats want to avoid that outcome.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — To impeach or not to impeach?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Surf Instructor Killed His Children and Claimed QAnon Made Him Do It, F.B.I. Says
description: Matthew Taylor Coleman, 40, of Santa Barbara, Calif., abducted his 2-year-old son and 10-month-old daughter and took them to Mexico, the authorities said.
content: A California surfing instructor confessed to killing his two children with a spearfishing gun after abducting them, telling investigators that his belief in the conspiracy theories known as QAnon made him do it, the authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Free Guy’ Review: Don’t Hate the Player
description: Ryan Reynolds brings his nice-guy charisma to the role of a video game character who doesn’t want to stay on the sidelines.
content: One day you’re just heading to your job at the bank, preparing for its daily spate of robberies, and the next you find out that you’re a side character in a video game. Tough break.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alice McDermott Is Reading ‘Frankenstein’ for the First Time
description: “The original is more complex, more overwrought and more harrowing than popular culture had led me to believe.”
content: “The original is more complex, more overwrought and more harrowing than popular culture had led me to believe,” says the novelist Alice McDermott, whose new book is “What About the Baby? Some Thoughts on the Art of Fiction.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Nicholas Fandos
title: Chuck Schumer Has Found a Way to Get It Done. So Far.
description: The majority leader has delivered preliminary success on the infrastructure and budget deals. But his priorities still have a long way to go to reach the president’s desk.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York ducked into the Democratic cloakroom on Tuesday to take a call on his old-school flip phone from President Biden. Senators were basking in a rare bipartisan success on infrastructure and gearing up for a more partisan budget brawl — and the president wanted to tell the majority leader he was a “magician.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in Pleasantville, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Bayville, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Blocks Part of New York’s Eviction Moratorium
description: The order applies only to a provision that bars evictions of tenants who file a form declaring economic hardship, rather than providing evidence in court.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday blocked part of an eviction moratorium in New York State that had been imposed in response to the coronavirus pandemic, a move the law’s supporters said might expose thousands to eviction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Reddit is valued at more than $10 billion in latest funding round.
description: Just six months ago it was valued at $6 billion. It raised $410 million in its latest round.
content: Reddit, the virtual town square of the consumer internet, has raised a fresh $410 million in funding, valuing it at more than $10 billion, the company said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Join Us for ‘On the Runway,’ a Virtual Event Series on Fashion
description: Our journalists will speak with designers, editors, C.E.O.s and influencers from around the world — beginning with an event on Sept. 7 with Anna Wintour.
content: How we shop — and dress — has changed radically. Supply chains continue to be disrupted. Luxury sales have spiked. How people will dress for the office (if they ever go back) remains to be seen. The fashion world is in flux — and adapting. On Sept. 7, New York Times fashion director Vanessa Friedman asks Anna Wintour, the artistic director of Condé Nast’s artistic director, and José Neves, the founder and C.E.O. of Farfetch, along with other industry leaders, what’s next, from the return of in-person runway shows to addressing social justice issues and sustainability — and, of course, what we’ll be wearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: When Dance Shut Down, These Directors Banded Together
description: Since last summer, leaders of New York’s pre-eminent dance companies have been meeting weekly to share ideas and problems.
content: Last summer, Jonathan Stafford, the artistic director of New York City Ballet, was feeling isolated and anxious. It was a few months into the pandemic, and the strangeness of lockdown and the turmoil and urgency of the Black Lives Matter protests were on his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Rare Mass Shooting in Britain Leaves 6 Dead, Including a Child
description: The killings in the southwestern city of Plymouth were not terrorism-related, a local member of Parliament said. It was the country’s first mass shooting since 2010.
content: Six people were fatally shot in Plymouth, England, on Thursday, a rare occurrence in a country that has some of the world’s strictest gun control laws and had not endured a mass shooting since 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Candy Stash
description: A husband keeps raiding his wife’s hidden stockpile of chocolate.
content: Christina writes: For years, I’ve kept some sweets hidden in a kitchen cabinet, out of the kids’ reach. Sometimes at the end of a long day, I just want a few bites of chocolate. But lately my husband Nate has been raiding my chocolate stash, finishing off whatever’s there. I don’t really care if he eats it, but he never replaces it. Please order him to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Facing Outrage Over Bikini Rule, Handball Federation Signals ‘Likely’ Change
description: In the weeks since Norway’s women’s beach handball team was fined for wearing shorts instead of bikini bottoms, other countries have increased pressure for a change in federation rules.
content: As Lucie Marie Kretzschmar, a beach handball player for Germany, was competing in a tournament in Romania, she noticed a front-row spectator filming intently with his phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Sicily Registers Record-High Temperature as Heat Wave Sweeps Italian Island
description: A monitoring station on the island reported a temperature of 119.84 Fahrenheit, 48.8 degrees Celsius, on Wednesday. If verified, it would be the highest ever recorded in Europe.
content: The Italian island of Sicily may have set a modern record for the hottest day ever recorded in Europe, with a monitoring station near the ancient city of Syracuse in the southeast recording a scorching 48.8 degrees Celsius, or 119.84 Fahrenheit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Documenting Grief, Faith and Tradition in Surfside
description: After following families in the Orthodox Jewish community as they buried loved ones killed in the condo collapse, a photographer discussed the sensitivities of the assignment.
content: When Mark Abramson, a freelance photographer based in New York and Los Angeles, saw the news of the condominium tower collapse in Surfside, Fla., on June 24 that killed 98 people, he started looking at cross-country flights. He didn’t have an assignment from any publication, but he knew he needed to be in the town, a suburb of Miami, to document what was happening to the community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Way the Senate Melted Down Over Crypto Is Very Revealing
description: It almost derailed the bipartisan infrastructure bill’s passage.
content: For months, there’s been a debate over what should count as infrastructure. Roads and bridges, sure. But what about preschool and health insurance and child care? Democrats say yes, Republicans say no. With the exception of broadband access, however, there’s been almost no discussion of the infrastructure underpinning the digital economy. But right at the end, that changed, when a meltdown over cryptocurrency regulation almost derailed the bipartisan infrastructure bill’s passage in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Helene Cooper, Lara Jakes and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Is Sending 3,000 Troops Back to Afghanistan to Begin Evacuations
description: With the Taliban sweeping across the country, U.S. officials say Kabul could fall in 30 days.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Pentagon is moving 3,000 Marines and soldiers to Afghanistan and another 4,000 troops to the region to evacuate most of the American Embassy and U.S. citizens in Kabul, as the Biden administration braces for a possible collapse of the Afghan government within the next month, administration and military officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: A Tale of Two Vineyards
description: Two sites near Paso Robles farm conscientiously, and both make excellent wines. But in the climate change era, one gets enough rain, the other doesn’t.
content: TEMPLETON, Calif. — This is a story of two wine producers in the Paso Robles region. They are different in size, background and intent, yet they have important elements in common, starting with a commitment to the land and to creating diverse, sustainable ecosystems. One is thriving, the other struggling to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘White as Snow’ Review: The Fairest of Them All
description: The director Anne Fontaine spins the Snow White fairy tale into a thriller, with Isabelle Huppert as the jealous stepmother.
content: Whatever rehabilitation wicked stepmothers have undergone of late encounters a setback in “White as Snow.” Isabelle Huppert brings a frost to her role as Maud in the director Anne Fontaine’s darkly playful gloss on the Snow White saga. Lou de Laâge portrays the hotelier’s shy, impossibly lovely stepdaughter and rival, Claire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Who Needs a Whirlwind Trip When You Can Take It Slow?
description: The slow travel movement has come into its own during the pandemic, as many travelers contemplate the need for more thoughtful, sustainable forms of exploring.
content: For many travelers, the prepandemic pace of whirlwind getaways and bucket-list-skimming trips seems so 2019. Now, as destinations cautiously reopen, travelers who spent a year or more confronted by climate change, social activism and a lack of human connection are embracing slow motion as a sustainable speed for exploring the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australian officials are criticized over ‘double quarantine’ for Olympians.
description: Sixteen athletes traveling to the state of South Australia must spend 28 days in quarantine. The country’s Olympic committee called the requirement “cruel.”
content: They traveled to Tokyo to compete for their country in the Summer Olympics, winning 46 medals for Australia in swimming, cycling, basketball and more. But that didn’t exempt Australian Olympians from their country’s strict rules for quarantine, which for some athletes is up to 28 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Some fear the pandemic and political turmoil may have affected the count.
description: The census was hobbled by the coronavirus and by a White House that tried to take undocumented immigrants out of the count to shift the balance of power.
content: Perhaps no census has been as fraught as the one that led to the data released on Thursday, a count pummeled by the pandemic and hobbled by a White House that sought to use it as a tool to permanently shift the balance of national political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: More Than 59,000 Pounds of Chicken Products Are Recalled
description: The recalled products may be contaminated and linked to a salmonella outbreak, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
content: An Indiana-based food manufacturer is recalling more than 59,000 pounds of chicken products that may be contaminated with Salmonella enteritidis, federal health officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. to Authorize Third Vaccine Dose for People With Weak Immune Systems
description: The decision to expand the emergency use of both the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines is meant to help transplant recipients and others whose immune systems are similarly compromised.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators are expected to authorize a third shot of coronavirus vaccine as soon as Thursday for certain people with weakened immune systems, an effort to better protect them as the highly contagious Delta variant sweeps the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Materna’ Review: Mommy Issues
description: Four unrelated women with serious emotional baggage are connected by an incident on the subway in this indie drama directed by David Gutnik.
content: In “Materna,” the debut feature by David Gutnik, four anguished New York women are connected by an incident on the subway involving — surprise, surprise — an unhinged man (Sturgill Simpson). Subtler and more focused than cloyingly grandiose interlocking dramas like “Crash,” it takes an interest — as the title suggests — in motherhood and mothering: the anxieties related to pregnancy and child-rearing; the guilt and frustrations born of generational rifts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Frank Torres, Judge Who Sought More Latinos on the Bench, Dies at 93
description: The son of one judge and the father of another, Justice Torres pressed for greater Hispanic representation in the legal profession and the New York courts.
content: Frank Torres, a former New York State Supreme Court justice who, as the son of a Family Court jurist and later the father of a federal judge, championed greater Hispanic representation in the legal profession and on the bench, died on Thursday in the Bronx. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli and Liz Day
title: Britney Spears’s Father Says He Will Step Aside in Conservatorship Battle
description: Lawyers for James P. Spears said he intended to work with the court to assure “an orderly transition to a new conservator,” while arguing that he should not be immediately removed.
content: In an abrupt reversal after more than a year of fighting in court — and a much longer battle behind the scenes — Britney Spears’s father has agreed to eventually step aside from his long-running role overseeing the singer’s finances as part of the unique conservatorship that has governed her life since 2008.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: In Texas, a Quarantine Camp for Migrants With Covid-19
description: A first look inside the camp where more than 1,000 migrants are being quarantined after testing positive for the virus. At least 1,000 others are also under isolation after positive Covid tests.
content: MISSION, Texas — On the edge of the Rio Grande in South Texas, sprawling Anzalduas Park has long been a popular spot for bird-watching, family cookouts and fishing. But earlier this month, the grassland expanse with barbecue grills and picnic tables was put off-limits, transformed into a large Covid-19 quarantine camp for migrants who have crossed from Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: At the Texas Capitol, a Day for Arrest Warrants, Not Legislation
description: The Texas House sergeant-at-arms spent his day delivering 52 civil arrest warrants to Democrats who fled rather than enact the Republican voting agenda.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Just after the Texas House of Representatives, well short of the quorum needed to pass legislation, quit for the day after meeting for less than an hour, Michael Black, the House sergeant-at-arms, left his office just outside the second-floor chamber to embark on an extraordinary mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Australians seek ways to speed vaccinations as government rollout sputters.
description: A stubborn Delta outbreak has kicked a complacent country into gear, with community members working to fill gaps in the government’s sputtering vaccine rollout.
content: All over Australia, hope is struggling to gain momentum as an outbreak of the hyper-contagious Delta variant has thrown almost half the population into lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: For Many, Hydrogen Is the Fuel of the Future. New Research Raises Doubts.
description: Industry has been promoting hydrogen as a reliable, next-generation fuel to power cars, heat homes and generate electricity. It may, in fact, be worse for the climate than previously thought.
content: It is seen by many as the clean energy of the future. Billions of dollars from the bipartisan infrastructure bill have been teed up to fund it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Long, Slow Drowning of the New Jersey Shore
description: Billions have been spent to protect the beachfront. But inch by inch, water is winning the war.
content: From a satellite’s point of view, New Jersey’s barrier islands barely register, like fine white bones pulled from a body of green, separated by a vascular tissue of wetlands and shallow bays. Twenty thousand years ago, when the Laurentide ice sheet covered much of Canada and the northern United States, the coast of what would be New Jersey reached to the edge of the continental shelf, nearly 100 miles east of the present shoreline. For the next 10,000 years, as the last ice age came to an end and the sea level rose by more than 300 feet, the New Jersey coastline moved steadily west.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Power outages add to the misery in the Midwest as sweltering heat seizes much of the U.S.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, storms and more.
content: More than 150 million people across the United States were under some form of heat alert on Thursday with baking temperatures expected in the Pacific Northwest, parts of the Plains and the South, and much of the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Celebrating Peak Summer
description: A quick weeknight sauté of ripe corn, tomatoes and seared halloumi is exactly what we love about summer.
content: For me, peak summer is that joyful moment when the tomatoes and corn are ready at the same time, and there’s enough of each to go absolutely nuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Rebecca Robbins
title: As Virus Cases Surge, Biden Administration Encourages More Use of Antibody Treatments
description: A top White House adviser said monoclonal antibody treatments, sometimes underused, could still be crucial in helping people with Covid-19 avoid getting very sick.
content: WASHINGTON — Facing overcrowded hospitals and an unrelenting surge of Delta variant cases around the country, the Biden administration on Thursday renewed its call for health providers to use monoclonal antibody treatments, which can help Covid-19 patients who are at risk of getting very sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” is back, and a scrappy new wrestling drama pits brother against brother, inside the ring and beyond.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for Watching here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Homeroom’ Review: Salutations for the Class of 2020
description: This documentary from Peter Nicks follows Oakland High School seniors as they fight for social justice and face Covid-19 on their way to graduation.
content: On their first day of school in 2019, members of the senior class at Oakland High School in Oakland, Calif., looked forward to Instagram posts and a year of tuning out teachers who drone on about math and classroom rules. More engaged classmates, like Denilson Garibo, a student governing board representative, might have anticipated that the year would include social justice organizing. But it would have been hard for the class of 2020 to predict the changes that the Covid-19 pandemic and the George Floyd protests would bring to their lives. This unprecedented year is captured in vérité style in the heartfelt documentary “Homeroom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Matthew Sedacca
title: Why Only 28 Percent of Young Black New Yorkers Are Vaccinated
description: As the Delta variant courses through New York City, many young Black New Yorkers remain distrustful of the vaccine.
content: A construction site safety manager in Queens said that as a Black man, he was more worried about the prospect of being stopped by the police than he was about getting Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan Inches Closer to Handing Over Ex-Dictator for Genocide Trial
description: An international court has accused Omar Hassan al-Bashir of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity in the western region of Darfur, where at least 300,000 were killed.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, in his first visit to the capital of Sudan, said Thursday he was hopeful that the Sudanese government would turn over former President Omar Hassan al-Bashir to face charges of genocide and war crimes in the region of Darfur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: No large city grew faster than Phoenix.
description: Arizona’s capital grew at the fastest rate among America’s biggest cities, vaulting it ahead of Philadelphia to officially become the fifth-biggest city in the U.S. since the last census.
content: The census numbers confirmed the scorching pace of growth in Phoenix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Mills, Chang W. Lee, James Hill, Hiroko Masuike and Alexandra Garcia
title: Our Photographers’ Favorite Olympic Images
description: Times photographers sought to capture every aspect of the Olympic Games in Tokyo. These pictures were special to them.
content: Over the last several weeks, a team of New York Times photographers sought to capture every aspect of the Olympic Games in Tokyo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Nation’s Largest L.G.B.T.Q. Advocacy Group in Turmoil Over Cuomo Ties
description: Alphonso David’s work for Gov. Andrew Cuomo helped him become leader of the largest L.G.B.T.Q. advocacy group in the country. Now those ties could cause his dismissal.
content: When Alphonso David became president of the nation’s largest L.G.B.T.Q.+ advocacy organization in 2019, his long experience as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s chief legal counsel and secretary on civil rights was seen as a huge advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Cuomo Has $18 Million in Campaign Cash. What Can He Do With It?
description: The huge war chest is the most money retained by a departing New York politician in recent memory.
content: Even after his resignation takes effect in less than two weeks, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will still control the largest pot of campaign cash in New York politics, an $18 million war chest amassed in apparent preparation for a run at a fourth term next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: In April, New York learned it lost a House seat after coming up 89 people short.
description: New population figures released on Monday confirmed that after the latest census, New York would lose a congressional seat, but only by the narrowest of margins.
content: New York’s congressional delegation will shrink by one seat after the 2022 election, but the state came excruciatingly close to snapping an eight-decade streak of declining representation in Washington: It was 89 residents short, to be precise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Searching for Mr. Rugoff’ Review: Man Behind the Movies
description: A documentary looks at an influential distributor and theater owner who went after visionary films, including “Scenes From a Marriage” and “Putney Swope.”
content: Not every documentary features its director calling his subject “kind of a terrible person.” But Ira Deutchman’s “Searching for Mr. Rugoff” happily looks at the man in full: Donald S. Rugoff, the influential distributor, New York City theater impresario and certifiable “piece of work” (to quote one testimonial).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: How the Infrastructure Bill Passed (the Senate)
description: The Senate passed Biden’s infrastructure bill with bipartisan support. Here’s how that happened.
content: When his $1 trillion infrastructure bill cleared the Senate with 19 Republican votes this week, President Biden achieved something the past two Democratic presidents never could: getting sizable bipartisan support for his top legislative priority. The bill now heads to the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Adidas sells Reebok to Authentic Brands for $2.5 billion.
description: In the past few years, Authentic has acquired Brooks Brothers and Forever 21, adding to a stable that includes Sports Illustrated.
content: Sixteen years after acquiring Reebok for $4 billion, the German sportswear giant Adidas is selling it for a little more than half that to Authentic Brands Group, the voracious acquirer of struggling brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yu Young Jin and Muktita Suhartono
title: Meet Delta, the good Samaritan robot in an Indonesia village.
description: The robot, made using a rice cooker and other household goods, is delivering food and other essential items to villagers infected with the virus.
content: Her name is Delta, her head is made from a discarded rice cooker, and she greets those self-isolating with “Assalamualaikum” — peace be upon you — when delivering essentials like food or disinfectant to villagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Extreme weather in Europe.
content: Fires around the northern parts of Evia, Greece’s second-largest island, have destroyed more than 120,000 acres of pine forest, razed homes and displaced hundreds of people. More than 20 countries have offered assistance in battling the blazes, and the Greek prime minister has declared them “a natural disaster of unprecedented dimensions.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Hughes
title: F.D.A. Approves GHB, a ‘Date Rape’ Drug, for Rare Sleeping Disorder
description: Jazz Pharmaceuticals brought in more than $1.7 billion last year selling GHB to narcolepsy patients. With the new approval, sales could soar.
content: In the 1960s, the drug was given to women during childbirth to dampen their consciousness. In the 1990s, an illicit version made headlines as a “date rape” drug, linked to dozens of deaths and sexual assaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: A New Must-Have for TV and Movie Shoots: Therapists
description: Working on set can be challenging. In Britain, many productions are hiring trained counselors to help casts and crew cope.
content: LONDON — When Lou Platt talks about her increasingly in-demand TV and movie production job, she has to make one thing clear: She can’t discuss 99 percent of the work itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Teaching a New Inclusiveness at The School
description: In ‘Feedback,’ a 21-artist knockout of a show, Helen Molesworth curates a nuanced and complicated conversation about race — the kind of talk we desperately need.
content: KINDERHOOK, N.Y. — Feedback is what you get when a system’s output is looped through its input, as when Jimi Hendrix, closing out the Woodstock music festival in 1969, used an electric guitar with an overdriven amplifier to turn a performance of “The Star-Spangled Banner” into a dizzying tone poem of anguish and destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Skateboarding to ‘Hamlet’ in New York
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: THE KING OF INFINITE SPACE, by Lyndsay Faye. (Putnam, $27.) Faye reimagines “Hamlet” in modern-day New York, where Ben Dane calls on his ex-fiancé, Lia, and best friend, Horatio, to piece together the death of his Broadway baron father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: Overlooked No More: Hettie Anderson, Sculptors’ Model Who Evaded Fame
description: Her image has been rendered on gold coins and monuments around the United States. But little is known about this Gilded Age model.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Beckett’ Review: He Must Go On
description: In this unthrilling thriller, John David Washington plays an Everyman who racks up a lot of miles while running on empty.
content: In “Beckett,” John David Washington plays a guy who keeps stumbling into trouble. He’s an ordinary man, or so we’re to believe. This conceit, though, is soon torpedoed both by a story that grows more implausible with each passing second and by his character’s gift for self-preservation. Especially impressive in this respect are his legs, which pump like pistons as he sprints through bullets and other dangers that keep getting in his way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Locked Down and Fed Up, Australians Find Their Own Ways to Speed Vaccinations
description: A stubborn Delta outbreak has kicked a complacent country into gear, with community members working to fill gaps in the government’s sputtering vaccine rollout.
content: HOWARD SPRINGS, Australia — After an order of the AstraZeneca coronavirus vaccine from the government never materialized, Quinn On realized on Monday that a busy pharmacy he manages in Western Sydney would soon run out of doses. He raced to pick up shots from one of his other stores, while his wife pleaded with local officials for extra supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Are Delta Symptoms Different?
description: We asked experts to describe the most prevalent symptoms they’re seeing right now among people with Covid-19.
content: Two years ago, a sneeze or a cough wouldn’t have been cause for concern, but now even the mildest of symptoms can leave us wondering, “Do I have Covid?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: New Work by Suzan-Lori Parks to Be Part of Public Theater Season
description: “The Visitor” and “cullud wattah,” two shows postponed by the pandemic, will get their premieres alongside works by James Ijames, Shaina Taub and Lloyd Suh.
content: The Public Theater’s 2021-22 season will feature a mix of projects postponed because of the pandemic and new works, including “Plays for the Plague Year” by Suzan-Lori Parks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Kamala Harris meets with business leaders to discuss child care.
description: Executives from companies like Airbnb, Chobani, Etsy and Microsoft were invited to the White House to drum up support for a pillar of President Biden’s $3.5 trillion budget.
content: The day after Senate Democrats passed their “big, bold” $3.5 trillion budget blueprint, Vice President Kamala Harris convened business leaders on Thursday to build corporate support for one of the plan’s pillars: child care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Finding a New Theater Audience, Far From France’s Cities
description: In rural gardens, forests and public squares, young stage artists fed up with the country’s rigid scene are striving for diversity and spontaneity.
content: MAURENS, France — The village of Maurens, 300 miles south of Paris, has a population of around 1,000. It has a church; a single bakery; and, since 2013, a summer theater festival, the Théâtre du Roi de Coeur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Don’t Let Inflation Anxiety Undermine Our Future
description: Please, Senator Manchin, do the math.
content: The lesson from Wednesday’s consumer price report was, to a large extent, in the eyes of the beholder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Sharif Hassan and Fahim Abed
title: Afghanistan Collapse Accelerates as the Taliban Capture 3 Vital Cities
description: Kandahar, Lashkar Gah and Herat have now fallen to the insurgents, who are racing to seize control of the entire country.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Three major cities in western and southern Afghanistan were confirmed on Friday to have fallen to the Taliban, as the insurgency’s race to seize control of the country accelerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Should We Worry As Billionaires Buy Up Newspapers?
description: LA Times owner Patrick Soon-Shiong says we should — and he’s one of those billionaires.
content: Patrick Soon-Shiong has some things in common with Rupert Murdoch and Jeff Bezos. He has billions of dollars, and he owns a media outlet — or several of them. In 2018, Soon-Shiong — who minted his fortune by inventing a cancer drug in the 1990s — scooped up the Los Angeles Times, the San Diego Union-Tribune and a group of smaller newspapers for a cool $500 million. Since then, he’s been obsessed with two things: modernizing his media empire and continuing his medical pursuits, most recently with an experimental Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: The largest U.S. teachers’ union announces support for vaccination or testing for educators.
description: The announcement comes after the leader of another major teachers’ union signaled strong support for vaccine mandates.
content: The nation’s largest teachers' union on Thursday offered its support to policies that would require all teachers to get vaccinated against Covid or submit to regular testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Meaning of Hitler’ Review: Understanding Fascism
description: This docu-essay inspired by Sebastian Haffner’s 1978 book of the same title argues that Hitler was disturbingly ordinary.
content: The docu-essay “The Meaning of Hitler” proceeds with caution. The film, inspired by the historian and journalist Sebastian Haffner’s 1978 book of the same title, seeks to understand the combination of personal pathology, political shrewdness and mass complicity that allowed Hitler to create the Nazi regime. It also finds disturbing 21st-century echoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Una Stubbs, Veteran Actress Known for ‘Sherlock,’ Dies at 84
description: Ms. Stubbs, a fixture on British television for more than half a century, was best known to American audiences as Sherlock Holmes’s cheerful landlady in the popular BBC series.
content: Una Stubbs, the veteran British actress best known to American audiences for her role as Mrs. Hudson, the landlady to Benedict Cumberbatch’s Sherlock Holmes in the BBC series “Sherlock,” died on Thursday at her home in Edinburgh. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff
title: Census Shows Sharply Growing Numbers of Hispanic, Asian and Multiracial Americans
description: Overall population growth slowed substantially over the past decade, but the number of multiracial Americans more than doubled.
content: The United States grew significantly more diverse over the past decade, as the populations of people who identify as Hispanic and Asian surged and the number of people who said they were more than one race more than doubled, the Census Bureau reported on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: What We Think We Know About Metabolism May Be Wrong
description: A new study challenges assumptions about energy expenditure by people, including the idea that metabolism slows at middle age.
content: Everyone knows conventional wisdom about metabolism: People put pounds on year after year from their 20s onward because their metabolisms slow down, especially around middle age. Women have slower metabolisms than men. That’s why they have a harder time controlling their weight. Menopause only makes things worse, slowing women’s metabolisms even more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘CODA’ Review: A Voice of Her Own
description: An openhearted embrace of deaf culture elevates this otherwise conventional tale of a talented teenager caught between ambition and loyalty.
content: The template of “CODA” — the title is also a term used to describe the hearing children of deaf adults — might be wearyingly familiar, but this warmhearted drama from Sian Heder opens up space for concerns that feel fresh.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: H.H.S. will require its health workers to get the Covid vaccine.
description: President Biden has been pushing for more agencies and companies to enforce similar rules as the Delta variant fuels a wave of new cases.
content: The Department of Health and Human Services on Thursday said it would require more than 25,000 health workers — including contractors and volunteers — to receive coronavirus vaccines, becoming the latest federal agency to implement such a mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Ryan Reynolds Power Up in ‘Free Guy’
description: The director Shawn Levy narrates a sequence where the character Guy discovers something new about the world he’s been living in.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Fauci calls booster shots ‘likely,’ not now but in future, citing early signs that vaccine immunity may wane.
description: Health officials are studying the durability of the vaccine in different groups, he said, and “we will be prepared to give boosters” if the vaccines’ protection ebbs.
content: With approval for additional Covid-19 vaccine shots for immunocompromised people “imminent,” Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the top U.S. infectious disease expert, said on Thursday that federal health authorities were “likely” to call for third shots as boosters for a broader swath of the population at some point, though there was no immediate need to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Garland presses state judges to stop evictions by connecting landlords and tenants to federal aid.
description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland held a virtual meeting with 35 state Supreme Court justices in an effort to encourage them to try to avert or delay evictions.
content: Biden administration officials, worried that a new freeze on evictions might be struck down in federal court — and racing to prevent a national crisis — are increasingly turning to state courts to help deliver billions in federal housing aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: The Department of Veterans Affairs will mandate vaccines for most workers in its medical centers.
description: The agency had already made shots compulsory for frontline workers. The change will impact more than 200,000 additional workers.
content: The Department of Veterans Affairs will require nearly every worker, volunteer and contractor within its vast health care system to be vaccinated against the coronavirus over the next eight weeks, in stark contrast to the Pentagon which has resisted immediate mandates for the country’s 1.3 million active-duty troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How the Delta Variant Is Affecting Wedding Season
description: With the new strain of Covid, couples are once again scrambling to make sense of how — or even whether — to move forward with their marriage plans.
content: Early this month, Fallon Carter was on the phone with a client working through a series of “what ifs.” Ms. Carter, who runs an event planning company in Manhattan, wanted to reassure a bride getting married in Anguilla next May that, should her guest count plummet, her bases were covered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: John Rizzo, C.I.A. Lawyer Who Sanctioned Waterboarding, Dies at 73
description: He defended the agency’s treatment of suspected terrorists, but he was later more reflective about it than most of his colleagues.
content: John Rizzo, the reflective but resolute Central Intelligence Agency lawyer who sanctioned the secret detention and torture of suspected Islamic militants after the attacks on New York and Washington on Sept. 11, 2001, and who approved drone strikes that targeted terrorists abroad but that were also blamed for killing and wounding countless civilians, died on Aug. 6 at his home in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand, After Holding Virus at Bay, Unveils Reopening Strategy
description: From early next year, vaccinated travelers from low-risk countries can enter New Zealand without having to quarantine.
content: New Zealand, a global standout in its success at fighting the coronavirus, unveiled a cautious plan for reopening on Thursday, vowing to retain its goal of zero coronavirus cases even as it begins to unseal its borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Not Going Quietly’ Review: Into the Long Fight
description: This documentary follows the activist Ady Barkan, who toured the U.S. to help demonstrators draw attention to public health policies after his diagnosis with a fatal neurological disease.
content: In 2016, Ady Barkan was working as an advocate for economic justice when he was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., a neurological disease that deteriorates motor function. Doctors told him he had only three or four years to live. The documentary “Not Going Quietly” begins shortly after this grim diagnosis, as Barkan embarks on a new political campaign, this time focused on public health policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: What the Dixie Fire Took From Hundreds of Residents
description: A reporter shares stories of loss and uncertainty from the second-largest blaze in state history. Plus, Gov. Gavin Newsom mandates vaccines for teachers.
content: GREENVILLE — After the Dixie fire tore through this remote mountain town, Mike Savala heard that his home was, miraculously, still standing. He did not know the fate of his two cats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Biden presses Congress to move on price controls for prescription drugs.
description: President Biden singled out drug prices as an issue he wanted to include in the Democrats’ $3.5 trillion social policy bill, including allowing Medicare to negotiate lower prices.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden implored Congress on Thursday to include strict controls on prescription drug prices in the mammoth social policy bill that Democrats plan to draft this fall, hitting on an issue that his predecessor campaigned on but failed to achieve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Oil turns a rural county in North Dakota into a boomtown.
description: McKenzie County in the west of the state grew faster than any American county, more than doubling in size as the Bakken oil boom attracted workers.
content: McKenzie County in western North Dakota grew at the fastest rate of any American county over the past decade, Census Bureau data showed, as the Bakken oil boom attracted thousands of workers and more than doubled the population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: After a long battle, firefighters contain some wildfires in Greece.
description: A thunderstorm was a mixed blessing: The rain doused some of the smoldering fires, but lightning sparked new ones.
content: ATHENS — After 10 days of battling blazes across the country, firefighters in Greece managed to contain some of them on Thursday, although a thunderstorm was a mixed blessing: the rain doused some of the smoldering fires but lightning sparked new ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The New York Times wants readers to pay for newsletters.
description: The Times will make 18 of its newsletters available only to subscribers but will keep flagship email offerings such as The Morning free.
content: The New York Times said on Thursday that it would make a slate of newsletters available only to subscribers, including new offerings from John McWhorter, Kara Swisher and other writers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Diversity rises in Georgia, with whites making up only half the state.
description: Census data showed that Georgia has seen a dramatic boom in ethnic and racial diversity in the last decade, a trend that is already having a profound effect on the politics of both the state and the nation.
content: Census data released on Thursday shows that Georgia, a state where white supremacy was for decades enshrined in law and custom, has seen a dramatic boom in ethnic and racial diversity in the last decade, a trend that is already having a profound effect on the politics of both the state and the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Top Stars in Tennis Choose Rest Ahead of the U.S. Open
description: The year’s final Grand Slam tournament begins in less than three weeks, but players including Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Serena Williams have chosen to skip the usual hardcourt warm-up events.
content: As the tennis tours warm up for the U.S. Open in the summer heat of North America, the sport’s most accomplished players will arrive in New York cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The East’ Review: Imperialist Blues
description: This thoroughly generic war movie explores the Netherlands’ colonial legacy in Indonesia.
content: At the tail-end of World War II, an armed conflict broke out that is known today as the Indonesian War of Independence. The Dutch, after having lost their former colony to the Japanese in 1942, regrouped and deployed forces to reconquer the archipelago in 1946. Naturally, Indonesian nationalists were having none of it. And perhaps even more predictably, the Dutch Army responded with a violent campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: McDonald’s Franchise Settles Suit Involving ‘Dog Diaper’ Masks
description: Workers at a California restaurant said inadequate safety measures, including unsuitable face coverings, were to blame for a Covid-19 outbreak.
content: There have been many confrontations over workplace safety since the pandemic began. One of the strangest has just been resolved: the case of the dog diapers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andie Taylor
title: I’m a Trans Runner, and You Might Not Like What I Have to Say
description: Trans athletes are trapped in a culture war. I’m not a cheater, but I may have an unfair advantage.
content: In the highly politicized debate over whether transgender women should be allowed to play women’s sports, opinions tend to divide into two starkly opposing camps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams
title: Next Up for a Trump Tabloid Ally: Trying to Make It in the Hamptons
description: Dylan Howard, known for the “catch and kill” deals during the #MeToo reckoning, teams up with an Italian publisher for a publication aimed at the Hamptons crowd.
content: In late May, the luxury brand Ferragamo threw a launch party to celebrate the Grazia Gazette: The Hamptons — the latest free publication in one of the country’s wealthiest enclaves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Lost Leonardo’ Review: Art, Money and Oligarchy
description: This documentary about the painting “Salvator Mundi” packs the fascination and wallop of an expertly executed fictional thriller.
content: To paraphrase John Lennon, Leonardo da Vinci is a concept by which world civilization (such as it is) measures artistic mastery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Days’ Review: A Taiwanese Auteur in a Quiet Mode
description: Tsai Ming-liang’s latest film has little dialogue and no subtitles, but has plenty of story to tell.
content: Writing about the punk band Ramones, the critic Robert Christgau said their music had “revealed how much you can take out and still have rock and roll.” With his new film “Days,” the Taiwan-based director Tsai Ming-liang reveals how much you can take out of a fictional feature and still have cinema.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon and Michael Wines
title: How the Census Bureau Stood Up to Donald Trump’s Meddling
description: The failed attempt would have benefited Republicans by sapping electoral strength from Democratic-leaning areas.
content: WASHINGTON — There were 10 days left in the Trump presidency. And John Abowd and Tori Velkoff had a decision to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Pawel
title: This Is How a Political Dynasty Bites the Dust
description: Andrew Cuomo inherited his father’s fierce competitive spirit, but not his humanity or introspection.
content: When I knew Andrew Cuomo, he was the 20-something top adviser to the governor he called Mario, and I was the 20-something Albany bureau chief for Newsday. I still remember how he ended our occasional phone calls: “Bye, hon,” hanging up immediately before I could protest. It was vintage Andrew — calculated and patronizing, a show of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Many Pandemic Retirees Weren’t Ready. How to Cope if You’re One of Them.
description: A significant portion of workers who left their jobs since the coronavirus began surging were financially unprepared, research shows.
content: Andrea Jones hadn’t yet settled on a date to retire from her customer service job at United Airlines when Newark airport started looking like a ghost town in March 2020. After 28 years with the carrier, she still loved her work. But by the end of that month, she had hung up her blue uniform for the last time. She is still struggling with a sense of loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Quoctrung Bui
title: Delta Variant Hasn’t Yet Changed Many Return-to-Office Plans
description: A recent survey finds most people report they are already back at their workplace or will be soon.
content: Even as many tech companies announce delays to their return-to-office dates in the face of the Delta variant, it appears that most companies’ plans have not yet changed, according to several weeks of surveys by Morning Consult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: First-Time Home Buyers Struggle
description: A study reveals that home prices in the 50 largest U.S. cities present a major challenge to inexperienced buyers.
content: The cutthroat home market has frustrated buyers across the country, with many submitting multiple offers only to be outbid again and again. Low inventory, high prices and intense competition are challenging for any buyer, but first-timer buyers are facing the highest hurdles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan
description: This week’s properties are in Ditmas Park, Astoria and on the Upper East Side.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Rick Rojas
title: The growth along the corridor between San Antonio and Austin is ‘kind of mind-blowing.’
description: Census officials confirmed what has long been plainly visible in the stretch of Central and South Texas: Many new people were moving in.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Not too long ago, the span of Interstate 35 in Texas linking San Antonio and Austin ran through a smattering of smaller cities and lots of wide-open land. Now, it’s a blur of subdivisions, commercial development and soul-crushing traffic, coalescing into a singular mass of population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frederick W. Kagan
title: Biden Could Have Stopped the Taliban. He Chose Not to.
description: A disastrous Taliban takeover wasn’t inevitable.
content: The Taliban is sweeping across Afghanistan seizing at least 10 provincial capitals in the past week, and is poised to seize more. Afghan defense forces, finding themselves mostly cut off from U.S. air support, haven’t been able to stop them, and the Afghan government may not survive for much longer. The United States has all but abandoned the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kat Eschner
title: New Books That Look at the Pandemic and Its Consequences
description: From the account of a new doctor to an insider’s look at the government response to Covid, four new titles that capture our reality.
content: A PANDEMIC IN RESIDENCEEssays From a Detroit HospitalBy Selina Mahmood133 pp. Belt Publishing. Paper, $16.95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audra D. S. Burch
title: The Villages, a retirement community in Florida, was the fastest-growing metro area over the last decade.
description: About a 45-minute drive from Orlando, the area’s population jumped 39 percent since 2010 — from about 93,000 residents to about 130,000.
content: MIAMI — Amid a slowing of overall population growth in the United States, a Florida retirement community continued its rise to the top of the population charts: The Villages, a sprawling master planned community in Central Florida, was the fastest-growing metropolitan area over the last decade, according to census data released Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Marginalized Groups Look to Get on the (Redistricting) Map
description: Underrepresented communities are mobilizing to stay intact and influential in newly drawn districts.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: This Boy Band Is the Joy That Hong Kong Needs Right Now
description: The popularity of the group, called Mirror, has offered the city a rare burst of unity and pleasure after years of political upheaval.
content: HONG KONG — They swarm public squares, crowd shopping malls and form lines that stretch several city blocks. They lean over barricades that strain to hold them and ignore police officers who try to corral them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Asks Taliban to Spare Its Embassy in Coming Fight for Kabul
description: The demand seeks to stave off an evacuation of the embassy by dangling aid to future Afghan governments — even one that includes the Taliban.
content: WASHINGTON — American negotiators are trying to extract assurances from the Taliban that they will not attack the U.S. Embassy in Kabul if the extremist group takes over the country’s government and ever wants to receive foreign aid, three American officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: We All Stand Corrected
description: Jake Halperin’s puzzle clears a lot of things up.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Wow, talk about a puzzle you can learn things from.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: In ‘My Unorthodox Life,’ Fashion Is a Flash Point
description: “Show me a law that says I cannot wear high-heeled shoes.”
content: Early in “My Unorthodox Life,” the Netflix reality series about Julia Haart, the fashion executive who turned her back on her strict religious upbringing for the high life in Manhattan, Batsheva, her elder daughter, strolls onto the set in a trim pair of jeans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Can America Really Drive Its Way Out of Climate Change?
description: Electric vehicles promise an easy resolution to the tension  between the need to halt climate change and America’s love of cars. Can they deliver?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Can We Ever Look at Titian’s Paintings the Same Way Again?
description: Great is what this art is, yet it raises doubts about whether any art, however “great,” can be considered exempt from moral scrutiny.
content: BOSTON — With its small supernova of a show, “Titian: Women, Myth & Power,” the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here scores an art historical coup that institutions many times its size should envy, and audiences, hungry for old master dazzle, can count themselves lucky to see. Yet the same exhibition raises troubling questions about how, in art from the distant past viewed through the lens of the political present, aesthetics and ethics can clash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: British Columbia Battles Nearly 300 Wildfires at Once. Here’s How.
description: The Canadian authorities are urging residents to obey evacuation orders during the worst wildfire season since a devastating one in 2018.
content: Whole parts of British Columbia are shrouded in opaque clouds of billowing smoke sent churning by the hundreds of wildfires that have been raging in the province’s interior region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naz Deravian
title: How to Stretch Saffron, Without Sacrificing Flavor
description: Nothing compares to saffron’s unique fragrance and flavor. With this time-honored method, the world’s priciest spice can play a role in daily cooking.
content: In the Iranian kitchen, the dizzying aroma of sweet saffron mingled with the warm, nutty scent of perfectly steamed rice is a time-honored call to the table. Even though it is known as the world’s most expensive spice, saffron is ubiquitous in Persian cuisine and infuses a wide array of dishes with soul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A Woolly Mammoth’s Tusks Reveal a Map of Where It Roamed in Life
description: The technique used to reconstruct the animal’s 28-year journey across prehistoric Alaska could solve mysteries about the demise of the elephant-like mammals.

title: 3 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
description: Lizania Cruz on the art of gathering testimonies; Arcmanoro Niles’s brilliantly hued portraits; and “Counter Flags” takes on the symbols of nationalism.
content: “¡Se buscan testigos!” Last year, Lizania Cruz painted this announcement — “looking for witnesses!” — on signs made of rice sacks, and posted them in urban outskirts in the Dominican Republic. Each posed a question about Dominican history and identity — Do you believe what you were taught about Christopher Columbus? Did you know that the plantain dish mangú was originated by enslaved Black people? — and provided a WhatsApp number for the public to send replies. Later, Cruz, who grew up there and now lives in New York City, brought the exercise to Washington Heights, where she pasted her appeal in bodegas, ran it in community newspapers and took to the street herself, with a prim coat and a briefcase, asking Dominican-Americans how they see their identity in each country.

title: Joy, Flexibility and Bravery Land on the Best-Seller List
description: In these semi-dark times, qualities of mercy are in demand for readers of all ages.
content: BITE-SIZE The tween attention span has been a subject of much concern, especially since the pandemic made “screen time” as quaint as rotary phones. Here’s a tip for adolescents transfixed by Roblox: Try anthologies. They’re the YouTube of books, perfect for easily distracted types, and there’s a new one at No. 1 on the middle grade hardcover list: “Black Boy Joy: 17 Stories Celebrating Black Boyhood,” edited by Kwame Mbalia, author of the Tristan Strong trilogy. His collection includes contributions from Jerry Craft, Tochi Onyebuchi and Jason Reynolds, and explores sexual identity, intergalactic warfare, skateboarding and loss. With irresistibly named tales like “There’s Going to Be a Fight in the Cafeteria on Friday and You Better Not Bring Batman,” the vibe is playful with a side of gravity; as Mbalia writes, “Grab your string cheese. Prepare to laugh, cry and maybe even dance, but most of all, prepare to feel joyful.” At the moment, “Black Boy Joy” is the only anthology on the middle grade list — but readers may also be interested in Joanna Farrow’s “The Official Harry Potter Baking Book,” currently at No. 3, which teaches kids how to whip up Wand Breadsticks, Quidditch Pitch Focaccia and Whomping Willow Cheese Straws.

content: Before dawn on Aug. 17, 1975, about 60 police officers and F.B.I. agents charged into the Brooklyn apartment of a fireman named Mel Patrick Lynch. The living room was dimly lit; its blinds were drawn. Mr. Lynch sat on the couch next to the unshaven, foul-smelling, bound and blindfolded 21-year-old scion of one of America’s richest families, Samuel Bronfman II, who had been missing for nine days.

author: By Mimi Vu
title: In Bogotá, a Designer’s Eclectic Home and Bonsai-Filled Garden
description: Eight years ago, Danielle Corona moved production for her accessories brand, Hunting Season, to Colombia, and then she set up house there herself.
content: The accessories designer Danielle Corona likes to say she has two competing sides. “On the one hand, I’m known for a very minimalist, modern aesthetic,” she explains. “But there’s another part of me that leans toward the more naturalistic and earthy.” These opposing tendencies come together in Hunting Season, the line of pared-back but textural handbags and travel pouches she founded in 2006. While its slim top-handled purses and boxy cross-bodies have precise, structured forms influenced by Corona’s time at European fashion brands such as Valentino and the Italian accessories line VBH, the pieces are in fact crafted by artisans in Colombia, where her company is based, who often use local plant fiber and cotton hand-weaving techniques that imbue them with warmth and a more organic feel.
